results.title: Water Harvesting
results.creator_credit: Kingcroft Productions, New South Wales. Milk Board and John Kingsford-Smith
results.brief_description: At the 400 acre Sydney University Animal Husbandry Farm at Badgery’s Creek an important experiment is being conducted into a system of internal irrigation known as water harvesting. Water is carried by contour drains and stored in earth dams. In dry periods, pastures are irrigated by mobile sprays and pumping equipment. Commentary by David Low.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kingcroft Productions, New South Wales. Milk Board and John Kingsford-Smith

results.title: Water from the sun
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, S.T. Evans and Nicholas Alexander
results.brief_description: The Coober Pedy Solar Still was constructed outside the opal mining town in 1966. It covers an area of almost two acres, and is now distilling plentiful supplies of brackish water into a reliable supply of domestic fresh water. Explains with animated diagrams how a Solar Still works, and shows an earlier prototype in Western Australia. Only recently has enough been learned about the thermal behaviour of Solar Stills for an economical design to be developed.

results.title: Water for the people
results.brief_description: In Iraq, a United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation team surveys dry desert lands; the Iraq Government builds dams to divert water from the Tigris and Euphrates. In Central America, during the six months’ dry season, the well that supplies the village of Loa de Ramos in El Salvador dries up. A World Health Organisation team works out plans to use water from a nearby spring.

results.title: Water for the city
results.creator_credit: Film Associates, Frank Stokes and Dan McCarroll
results.brief_description: Demonstrates that water needed by people in a city begins as rain and snow that form rivers, lakes and underground water basins. Depicts the ways in which this water is purified and brought into homes in the city. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Water for Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Cine Service Productions, Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works and Geoffrey Thompson
results.brief_description: Traces the development of Melbourne’s water supply and depicts the steps taken to augment the Thomson River Scheme Projection of requirements to the year 2000. Also shown is the building of the Upper Thomson construction township and the planning, engineering, and conservation requirements of such a major scheme. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Water erosion and waterlogging
results.creator_credit: Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture and Gerry North
results.brief_description: Water erosion can result in the complete degradation of land by the removal of topsoils to expose infertile clay subsoils. The adoption of minimum tillage and other farm management techniques can lessen the risk of water erosion and improve farm productivity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture and Gerry North

results.title: Water conservation
results.creator_credit: Guild House Films, David Cobham Productions, Film Producers Guild, David Cobham and Simon Campbell-Jones
results.brief_description: Explains the advantages to the farmer of having his own water conservation scheme. Shows how a small reservoir can be constructed to make water available for irrigation purposes during the summer. Hints are given on siting, selection of water source and use of plastic or waterproof linings.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Guild House Films, David Cobham Productions, Film Producers Guild, David Cobham and Simon Campbell-Jones

results.title: Water Babies
results.brief_description: Shows how to teach young children to control their breathing in water, how to teach them to float, kick their feet and use their arms, and then further develop their water skills. Children who have been properly and safely made aware of water are given the confidence everyone needs when learning to swim.

results.title: Water and romi = Air dan romi
results.creator_credit: S E T Film Workshop and Garin Nugroho
results.brief_description: This documentary was produced for the International Seminar on Water, held in Jakarta in December 1991 under the auspices of the Goethe Institute, Indonesia. Water mongers and river cleaners, amongst others, are interviewed in this look at life along the rivers and the worrying condition of water supply in the bustling city of Jakarta. The film was banned by Suharto’s New Order Government. In Bahasa Indonesia with English subtitles.

results.title: Water against wildfire
results.creator_credit: Kestrel Films (Australia), Victorian Film Corporation, John Richardson and David Morgan
results.brief_description: This film was made at the request of Victoria’s Forest Commission. Bush fires all over Australia and indeed all parts of the world create havoc not only on the environment of humans but also on the delicate balance of the natural world. A training film directed towards forest workers on how to use water on forest fires and the follow-up after the fire has been contained.
